main event: On December 22, 1951, a pilot flying an F-84 aircraft observed an unidentified object near Columbus, Ohio, which appeared to be an airplane without a tail section and was silver in color. The object was on a heading of about 300Â°, traveling at a high speed and making rolling or tumbling maneuvers before being lost in the sun.
interesting points: The object was observed for approximately one and a half minutes, during which the pilot attempted to intercept it but lost it when turning into the sun.
The pilot had approximately 1700 flying hours and combat experience as a fighter pilot during World War II, indicating the high reliability of the observer.
No trail or exhaust was seen from the object, and no sound was heard. The reported actions of the object could not be explained satisfactorily.
The pilot's opinion was that the object was probably a balloon about 1000 to 1500 feet in diameter, but the high speed and maneuvering of the object could not be attributed to a balloon.

The sighting prompted a request for information about a balloon release near Columbus, Ohio, at the same time as the observation, suggesting a potential connection between the observed object and the balloon.
sighted object: unidentified object resembling an airplane without a tail section, silver in color
witnesses: Pilot of an F-84 aircraft, a highly experienced jet fighter pilot
